elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0005">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">(a) ORTEP representation of the symmetry expanded local structure for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> showing 30% thermal ellipsoids. (b) The structure of the two-dimensional coordination layer with the corrugated surface viewed along the crystallographic <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis. (c) View of two-dimensional (4,4)-coordination layer in the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, showing the tetrahedral coordination mode around the silver ions. The hydrogen atoms, CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules have been omitted for clarity. (d) Packing diagram of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> viewed down the crystallographic <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis. Uncoordinated CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> counterions are located in the channels. The H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules have been omitted for clarity. (e) Space-filling diagram of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. These channels, viewed down the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis, are filled by the uncoordinated CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions. H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules have been omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1abc"></ce:link>
<ce:link locator="gr1de"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) ORTEP representation of the symmetry expanded local structure for 1 showing 30% thermal ellipsoids. (b) The structure of the two-dimensional coordination layer with the corrugated surface viewed along the crystallographic a axis. (c) View of two-dimensional (4,4)-coordination layer in the structure of 1, showing the tetrahedral coordination mode around the silver ions. The hydrogen atoms, CF3SO3 - anions and H2O molecules have been omitted for clarity. (d) Packing diagram of 1 viewed down the crystallographic b axis. Uncoordinated CF3SO3 - counterions are located in the channels. The H2O molecules have been omitted for clarity. (e) Space-filling diagram of 1. These channels, viewed down the b axis, are filled by the uncoordinated CF3SO3 - anions. H2O molecules have been omitted for clarity.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0010">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0010">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">(a) ORTEP representation of the asymmetric unit expanded local structure for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (30% thermal ellipsoids). (b) A part of the one-dimensional right-handed helical chain of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> propagating along the crystallographic <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis. (c) Six successive Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> units form a hexagonal structure viewed down the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis. (d) Right-handed 6<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> helical chain of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> built from alternating Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> units and <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>. (e) View of the single-strand helical chain of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> that shows a chiral nanochannel with an opening of ∼1.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm along the [1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0] direction, free H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> have been omitted.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2abc"></ce:link>
<ce:link locator="gr2de"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) ORTEP representation of the asymmetric unit expanded local structure for 2 (30% thermal ellipsoids). (b) A part of the one-dimensional right-handed helical chain of 2 propagating along the crystallographic c axis. (c) Six successive Cd(NO3)(H2O)3 units form a hexagonal structure viewed down the c axis. (d) Right-handed 61 helical chain of 2 built from alternating Cd(NO3)(H2O)3 units and L2 . (e) View of the single-strand helical chain of 2 that shows a chiral nanochannel with an opening of ~1.2×1.2nm along the [100] direction, free H2O and NO3 - have been omitted.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0015">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cn0015">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">(a) View of the one-dimensional right-handed helical chain extending along the crystallographic <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis. The hydrogen bonds connecting adjacent chains are shown as dashed lines. (b) View of the chiral chains extending along the crystallographic <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis to form a periodically ordered interlocking architecture. (c) View of the one-dimensional right-handed helical chain extending along the crystallographic <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis. The hydrogen bonds connecting adjacent chains are shown as dashed lines. (d) View of the chiral chains in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> extending along the crystallographic <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis to form a periodically ordered interlocking architecture. (e) View of how the chiral chains in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are extended in parallel to form the wave-like structure. (f) and (g) Schematic diagrams showing the open channels within the quasi three-dimensional chiral framework of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The uncoordinated NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions are located in the channels. H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules are not shown.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3abc"></ce:link>
<ce:link locator="gr3de"></ce:link>
<ce:link locator="gr3fg"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  (a) View of the one-dimensional right-handed helical chain extending along the crystallographic b axis. The hydrogen bonds connecting adjacent chains are shown as dashed lines. (b) View of the chiral chains extending along the crystallographic b axis to form a periodically ordered interlocking architecture. (c) View of the one-dimensional right-handed helical chain extending along the crystallographic a axis. The hydrogen bonds connecting adjacent chains are shown as dashed lines. (d) View of the chiral chains in 2 extending along the crystallographic a axis to form a periodically ordered interlocking architecture. (e) View of how the chiral chains in 2 are extended in parallel to form the wave-like structure. (f) and (g) Schematic diagrams showing the open channels within the quasi three-dimensional chiral framework of 2. The uncoordinated NO3 - anions are located in the channels. H2O molecules are not shown.

<ce:section-title id="st050">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">The self-assembly of periodically ordered coordination polymers and interlocked homochiral nanochannels based on helical chains that are built from chiral rigid bidentate bridging ligands and linear metal-connecting points have been reported.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

The self-assembly of periodically ordered coordination polymers and interlocked homochiral nanochannels based on helical chains that are built from chiral rigid bidentate bridging ligands and linear metal-connecting points have been reported.

</ce:bold> with Cd(II) ions has been investigated. The structure of {[Ag(<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>

</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>·NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) forms an infinite single helical chain with a pitch of 47.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. When viewed from the top of the chain, the infinite helical chain forms the wall of a hexagonal nanochannel with an opening of ∼1.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two diastereopure ligands, N,N'-bis(4-pyridyl)idene(1R,2R)- diaminocyclohexane (L1 ) and N,N'-bis(3-pyridyl)idene(1R,2R)-diaminocyclohexane (L2 ), have been synthesized and characterized. The interaction of L1  with Ag(I) ions and L2  with Cd(II) ions has been investigated. The structure of {[Ag(L1 )2](CF3SO3)⋅4H2O} n  (1) exhibits a (4,4)-connected two-dimensional sheet with a corrugated surface and the complex [Cd(L2 )2(NO3)(3H2O)]n⋅NO3⋅2H2O (2) forms an infinite single helical chain with a pitch of 47.25Å. When viewed from the top of the chain, the infinite helical chain forms the wall of a hexagonal nanochannel with an opening of ~1.2×1.2nm.

<ce:section-title id="st005">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Over the past decades, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as an important new class of porous materials with the potential for making a significant impact in the fields of separation, gas storage, catalysis and chemical sensing . The versatile pore features of MOFs, such as Lewis acidity, hydrophobicity, redox activity, basicity, chirality, which result from the precise arrangement of the transition metals and the organic functional groups, play a key role in the creation of unique nanosized reaction media. For instance, Pluth et al. have provided examples of p<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> shifts in metal–organic frameworks, and exploited the p<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> shifts to promote the acid catalyzed hydrolysis in basic solution . Such strategies exhibited a simple but useful way to modify the acidity or basicity properties of the substrate by supramolecular inclusion, and paved the way for the application of MOFs in catalysis and biomimetics. Among of these MOFs materials, N-containing heterocyclic bidentate ligands for the construction of some unique porous materials have been designed and synthesized, and their potential applications have now been well documented. However, the use of chiral diamines, such as trans-1R,2R-diaminocyclohexane, for the synthesis of chiral Schiff base ligands derived from formacyl pyridine have not received much attention .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past decades, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as an important new class of porous materials with the potential for making a significant impact in the fields of separation, gas storage, catalysis and chemical sensing . The versatile pore features of MOFs, such as Lewis acidity, hydrophobicity, redox activity, basicity, chirality, which result from the precise arrangement of the transition metals and the organic functional groups, play a key role in the creation of unique nanosized reaction media. For instance, Pluth et al. have provided examples of pK a shifts in metal-organic frameworks, and exploited the pK a shifts to promote the acid catalyzed hydrolysis in basic solution . Such strategies exhibited a simple but useful way to modify the acidity or basicity properties of the substrate by supramolecular inclusion, and paved the way for the application of MOFs in catalysis and biomimetics. Among of these MOFs materials, N-containing heterocyclic bidentate ligands for the construction of some unique porous materials have been designed and synthesized, and their potential applications have now been well documented. However, the use of chiral diamines, such as trans-1R,2R-diaminocyclohexane, for the synthesis of chiral Schiff base ligands derived from formacyl pyridine have not received much attention .

Experimental

All reagents required for the syntheses were obtained commercially and were either used as supplied or purified by standard methods prior to use. Elemental (C, H, N) analyses were obtained with a Vario ELIII elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded using KBr pellets on a Bio-Rad FTIR spectrophotometer in the 400-4000cm-1 range. The synthesis of L1  and L2  was based on previous literature .

Synthesis of {[Ag(L1 )2]⋅(CF3SO3)⋅4H2O} n  (1)

Ag(CF3SO3) 0.257g (1mmol) in ethanol (10mL) was added dropwise with stirring to L1  (0.292g, 1mmol) in ethanol (10mL) and stirring was continued at room temperature for 2h. Then the reaction mixture was kept in a refrigerator overnight. A white amorphous solid separated out. The solid was collected by filtration, washed with a few drops of methanol and dried at room temperature to give 1 as a white solid in 43% yield. The solid was dissolved in excess ethanol at room temperature, and slow evaporation of this solution yielded colorless block-shaped single crystals that proved suitable for X-ray analysis. FTIR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3467(m), 3137(s), 2940(s), 2861(m), 1643(s), 1597(s), 1556(m), 1451(w), 1408(s), 1323(w), 1271(s), 1230(m), 1170(m), 1035(s), 936(m), 820(s), 649(s), 541(w), 458(w), 436(m). elements.clean_text:
X-ray data collection and structure determinations

Single crystal X-ray diffraction studies of 1 and 2 were performed at room temperature on a Bruker Smart Apex single crystal diffractometer using the φ-ω scan method. The data were collected using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). Unit cell dimensions were obtained using least-squares refinements, and multiscan absorption corrections were applied using the sadabs program. Two water molecules in the unit cell of complex 2 have been omitted by the squeeze option of the platon program. Both structures were solved by direct methods using the program shelxs86 in the winGX package . Crystallographic data are summarized in  , whilst selected bond lengths and angles are given in  .

</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>

<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) consists of one silver atom and two <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligand molecules (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a). In each ligand molecule (N,N′-bis(4-pyridyl)idene-1R,2R-diaminocyclohexane), the inner imino N-atoms are oriented in different directions, with the nearly gauche N–C–C–N torsion angles equal to 59.71° and 63.99°, which makes them inert to metal ion coordination. As a result, only the peripheral pyridyls coordinate to the silver ions. Every silver ion has a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment, being bound to four nitrogen donors from the four adjacent molecules of <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>, with Ag–N bond distances in the range 2.247(3)–2.423(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and bond angles around the neighboring atoms ranging from 89.0(1)° to 143.4(1)°. The Ag(I) centers are extended by <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligands along two directions (b), resulting in a (4,4)-connected two-dimensional layer with a corrugated surface, in which four <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligands bridge four adjacent Ag atoms to form a 60-membered metallocycle with two opposite Ag⋯Ag distances of 17.758 and 13.256<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (c). Significantly, these two-dimensional layers stack in a parallel fashion, producing a one-dimensional channel when viewed down the crystallographic <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis (d and e). These channels are filled by the uncoordinated CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions and guest H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules. The shortest Ag⋯Ag distance between adjacent layers is 9.182<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. This result suggests that similar coordination complexes can be formed by <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligands and silvers ions, even when different counter anions are used . However, if the 4-substituted pyridine moiety on <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> was replaced by a 3-substituted pyridine moiety (<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>), we found that a one-dimensional helical chain of <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> with Cd(II) can be formed (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal Structure of {[Ag(L1 )2]⋅(CF3SO3)⋅4H2O} n  (1)

The asymmetric unit of {[Ag(L 1)2]⋅(CF3SO3)⋅4H2O} n  (1) consists of one silver atom and two L1  ligand molecules ( a). In each ligand molecule (N,N'-bis(4-pyridyl)idene-1R,2R-diaminocyclohexane), the inner imino N-atoms are oriented in different directions, with the nearly gauche N-C-C-N torsion angles equal to 59.71° and 63.99°, which makes them inert to metal ion coordination. As a result, only the peripheral pyridyls coordinate to the silver ions. Every silver ion has a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment, being bound to four nitrogen donors from the four adjacent molecules of L1 , with Ag-N bond distances in the range 2.247(3)-2.423(4)Å, and bond angles around the neighboring atoms ranging from 89.0(1)° to 143.4(1)°. The Ag(I) centers are extended by L1  ligands along two directions (b), resulting in a (4,4)-connected two-dimensional layer with a corrugated surface, in which four L1  ligands bridge four adjacent Ag atoms to form a 60-membered metallocycle with two opposite Ag⋯Ag distances of 17.758 and 13.256Å (c). Significantly, these two-dimensional layers stack in a parallel fashion, producing a one-dimensional channel when viewed down the crystallographic b axis (d and e). These channels are filled by the uncoordinated CF3SO3 - anions and guest H2O molecules. The shortest Ag⋯Ag distance between adjacent layers is 9.182Å. This result suggests that similar coordination complexes can be formed by L1  ligands and silvers ions, even when different counter anions are used . However, if the 4-substituted pyridine moiety on L1  was replaced by a 3-substituted pyridine moiety (L2 ), we found that a one-dimensional helical chain of L2  with Cd(II) can be formed ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st040">Crystal Structure of {[Cd<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Inorganic and organic nanochannels, such as nanotubes, have received considerable attention due to their potential applications in nanoelectronics, molecular devices and sensors, ion exchange and catalysis . It is possible to construct nanotubular structures using metal–organic helices containing bidentate bridging ligands as the building blocks . We surmise that the twisted binding sites of chiral rigid bidentate bridging ligands based on the N,N′-1R,2R-bicyclohexyl unit will induce the formation of helical structures when linked by a linear metal-connecting point. In this work we report the metal–organic nanotubular structure of {[Cd<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the chiral space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>6<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>, with one cadmium atom, one <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligand, one coordinated nitrate anion, three coordinated water molecules, one uncoordinated nitrate anion and two guest water molecules in the asymmetric unit. In the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (a), each Cd(II) atom is seven-coordinated to two nitrogen atoms that come from two different <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligands, one bidentate nitrate anion occupying two coordination sites, and three oxygen atoms from three different water molecules. The coordination environment around the cadmium centre can be described as a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal, with a Cd–N bond distance of 2.298(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and Cd–O bond distances ranging from 2.296(6) to 2.534(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The N–Cd–N bond angle is 174.51(2)°, and the O–Cd–O bond angles range from 46.96(2)° to 83.39(9)°. Due to the reciprocal arrangement of the two C–N<ce:inf loc="post">imine</ce:inf> bonds in the rigid R,R-1,2-bicyclohexyl moiety, the adjacent cadmium centers are connected to each other by the nitrogen donors (pyridyl) of the bridging bidentate <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligands to form an infinite right-handed helical chain with a pitch of 47.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, with each period corresponding to six <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligands (b). When viewed along the crystallographic <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis, the six successive Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> units are bridged by the bidentate backbones of <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> to form a hexagonal structure (c). elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[CdL2 (NO3)(3H2O)]⋅NO3⋅2H2O}n (2)

Inorganic and organic nanochannels, such as nanotubes, have received considerable attention due to their potential applications in nanoelectronics, molecular devices and sensors, ion exchange and catalysis . It is possible to construct nanotubular structures using metal-organic helices containing bidentate bridging ligands as the building blocks . We surmise that the twisted binding sites of chiral rigid bidentate bridging ligands based on the N,N'-1R,2R-bicyclohexyl unit will induce the formation of helical structures when linked by a linear metal-connecting point. In this work we report the metal-organic nanotubular structure of {[CdL2 (NO3)(3H2O)]⋅NO3⋅2H2O} n  (2). Compound 2 crystallizes in the chiral space group P61, with one cadmium atom, one L2  ligand, one coordinated nitrate anion, three coordinated water molecules, one uncoordinated nitrate anion and two guest water molecules in the asymmetric unit. In the asymmetric unit of 2 (a), each Cd(II) atom is seven-coordinated to two nitrogen atoms that come from two different L2  ligands, one bidentate nitrate anion occupying two coordination sites, and three oxygen atoms from three different water molecules. The coordination environment around the cadmium centre can be described as a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal, with a Cd-N bond distance of 2.298(4)Å and Cd-O bond distances ranging from 2.296(6) to 2.534(6)Å. The N-Cd-N bond angle is 174.51(2)°, and the O-Cd-O bond angles range from 46.96(2)° to 83.39(9)°. Due to the reciprocal arrangement of the two C-Nimine bonds in the rigid R,R-1,2-bicyclohexyl moiety, the adjacent cadmium centers are connected to each other by the nitrogen donors (pyridyl) of the bridging bidentate L2  ligands to form an infinite right-handed helical chain with a pitch of 47.25Å, with each period corresponding to six L2  ligands (b). When viewed along the crystallographic c axis, the six successive Cd(NO3)(H2O)3 units are bridged by the bidentate backbones of L2  to form a hexagonal structure (c). Of particular interest is the observation that with the infinite helical chain running along the crystallographic c axis (d), the hexagonal structures are packed in an overlapping fashion around the crystallographic 61 axis to generate a huge one-dimensional hexagonal nanotube with an opening of ~1.2×1.2nm (e).

<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">The individual one-dimensional right-handed helical chain is extended along two parallel directions. The one-dimensional right-handed helical chains are extended in parallel to give a corrugated layer along the crystallographic <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis, whilst the adjacent chains are linked mainly via O(W)–H⋯N hydrogen bonds between the adjacent chains and O(W)–H⋯O bridging hydrogen bonds involving guest water molecules (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>a). When viewed along the crystallographic <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis, these helical chains intertwine with each other to give a periodically ordered interlocking architecture (b). The hexagonal structures are stacked in a parallel and overlapping fashion to form interlocked channels, which are partly filled with uncoordinated NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions and guest water molecules. Simultaneously, the one-dimensional right-handed helical chains are extended in parallel to give a corrugated layer along the crystallographic <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis to give two-dimensional chiral layers in the crystallographic <ce:italic>ac</ce:italic> plane. Other hydrogen bonding interactions are also present between the above layers (c). When viewed along the crystallographic <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis the structure shows a periodically ordered interlocking architecture (d); if this is taken into account, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be considered as a quasi three-dimensional arrangement viewed from slightly off the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis (e). The shortest Cd⋯Cd distance between adjacent chains is 9.375<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. When viewed along the crystallographic <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis, the partly overlapping nanochannels lead to a quasi three-dimensional chiral framework with smaller open channels (f and g). The channel looks more cylindrical than hexagonal, with the inner diameter being about 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and being filled with uncoordinated NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions and guest water molecules.</ce:para>

When viewed along the crystallographic c axis, these helical chains intertwine with each other to give a periodically ordered interlocking architecture (b). The hexagonal structures are stacked in a parallel and overlapping fashion to form interlocked channels, which are partly filled with uncoordinated NO3 - anions and guest water molecules. Simultaneously, the one-dimensional right-handed helical chains are extended in parallel to give a corrugated layer along the crystallographic a axis to give two-dimensional chiral layers in the crystallographic ac plane. <ce:section-title id="st045">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">In this paper we report that the interaction of the diastereopure bipyridyl ligands N,N′-bis(4-pyridyl)idene(1R,2R)-diaminocyclohexane (<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>) with Ag(I) and N,N′-bis(3-pyridyl)idene(1R,2R)-diaminocyclohexane (<ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>) with Cd(II) ions provides a facile means of generating two types of coordination polymers. In particular, a self-assembly of periodically ordered interlocked homochiral nanochannels based on helical chains that are built from the chiral rigid bidentate <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> ligand and linear metal-connecting points was observed. This study demonstrates that the pyridyl-containing bidentate ligands <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:bold> are capable of coordinating metal centers with both N<ce:inf loc="post">pyridyl</ce:inf> donors and generate novel coordination polymers. The relative orientation of the nitrogen donors on the pyridyl rings and different metal centers are the determining factors in the structural topology of the metal–organic supramolecular architectures . Further studies using other metal centers for the construction of novel coordination-based networks and their properties such as enantioselective separation and catalysis are under way in our laboratory.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this paper we report that the interaction of the diastereopure bipyridyl ligands N,N'-bis(4-pyridyl)idene(1R,2R)-diaminocyclohexane (L1 ) with Ag(I) and N,N'-bis(3-pyridyl)idene(1R,2R)-diaminocyclohexane (L2 ) with Cd(II) ions provides a facile means of generating two types of coordination polymers. In particular, a self-assembly of periodically ordered interlocked homochiral nanochannels based on helical chains that are built from the chiral rigid bidentate L2  ligand and linear metal-connecting points was observed. This study demonstrates that the pyridyl-containing bidentate ligands L1  and L2  are capable of coordinating metal centers with both Npyridyl donors and generate novel coordination polymers. The relative orientation of the nitrogen donors on the pyridyl rings and different metal centers are the determining factors in the structural topology of the metal-organic supramolecular architectures . Further studies using other metal centers for the construction of novel coordination-based networks and their properties such as enantioselective separation and catalysis are under way in our laboratory.

Synthesis of {[Ag(L1 )2]⋅(CF3SO3)⋅4H2O} n  (1)

Ag(CF3SO3) 0.257g (1mmol) in ethanol (10mL) was added dropwise with stirring to L1  (0.292g, 1mmol) in ethanol (10mL) and stirring was continued at room temperature for 2h. Then the reaction mixture was kept in a refrigerator overnight. A white amorphous solid separated out. The solid was collected by filtration, washed with a few drops of methanol and dried at room temperature to give 1 as a white solid in 43% yield. The solid was dissolved in excess ethanol at room temperature, and slow evaporation of this solution yielded colorless block-shaped single crystals that proved suitable for X-ray analysis. FTIR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3467(m), 3137(s), 2940(s), 2861(m), 1643(s), 1597(s), 1556(m), 1451(w), 1408(s), 1323(w), 1271(s), 1230(m), 1170(m), 1035(s), 936(m), 820(s), 649(s), 541(w), 458(w), 436(m). Anal. Calc. for C37H48AgF3N8O7S: C 48.63; H 5.29; N 12.26. Found: C, 48.70; H, 5.22; N, 12.32%.

Synthesis of {[CdL2 (NO3)(3H2O)]⋅NO3⋅2H2O} n  (2)

Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (308mg, 1mmol) in ethanol (10mL) was added slowly to a stirred solution of L2  (292mg, 1mmol) in ethanol (10mL) and stirring was continued at room temperature for 2h. The initial white precipitate that formed was filtered off. The filtrate was allowed to evaporate slowly to yield colorless single crystals, one of which was removed from the solution and used directly for X-ray analysis. Yield: 35%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3435(w), 3133(m), 2934(w), 1644(w), 1388(s), 1197(w), 1131(w), 982(w), 940(w), 820(w), 702(w), 646(w). Anal. Calc. for C18H30CdN6O11: C 34.93; H 4.89; N 13.58. Found: C, 34.85; H, 4.82; N, 13.65%.

Results and discussion

Crystal Structure of {[Ag(L1 )2]⋅(CF3SO3)⋅4H2O} n  (1)

The asymmetric unit of {[Ag(L 1)2]⋅(CF3SO3)⋅4H2O} n  (1) consists of one silver atom and two L1  ligand molecules ( a). In each ligand molecule (N,N'-bis(4-pyridyl)idene-1R,2R-diaminocyclohexane), the inner imino N-atoms are oriented in different directions, with the nearly gauche N-C-C-N torsion angles equal to 59.71° and 63.99°, which makes them inert to metal ion coordination. As a result, only the peripheral pyridyls coordinate to the silver ions. Every silver ion has a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment, being bound to four nitrogen donors from the four adjacent molecules of L1 , with Ag-N bond distances in the range 2.247(3)-2.423(4)Å, and bond angles around the neighboring atoms ranging from 89.0(1)° to 143.4(1)°. The Ag(I) centers are extended by L1  ligands along two directions (b), resulting in a (4,4)-connected two-dimensional layer with a corrugated surface, in which four L1  ligands bridge four adjacent Ag atoms to form a 60-membered metallocycle with two opposite Ag⋯Ag distances of 17.758 and 13.256Å (c). Significantly, these two-dimensional layers stack in a parallel fashion, producing a one-dimensional channel when viewed down the crystallographic b axis (d and e). These channels are filled by the uncoordinated CF3SO3 - anions and guest H2O molecules. The shortest Ag⋯Ag distance between adjacent layers is 9.182Å. This result suggests that similar coordination complexes can be formed by L1  ligands and silvers ions, even when different counter anions are used . However, if the 4-substituted pyridine moiety on L1  was replaced by a 3-substituted pyridine moiety (L2 ), we found that a one-dimensional helical chain of L2  with Cd(II) can be formed ( ).

Crystal Structure of {[CdL2 (NO3)(3H2O)]⋅NO3⋅2H2O}n (2)

Inorganic and organic nanochannels, such as nanotubes, have received considerable attention due to their potential applications in nanoelectronics, molecular devices and sensors, ion exchange and catalysis . It is possible to construct nanotubular structures using metal-organic helices containing bidentate bridging ligands as the building blocks . We surmise that the twisted binding sites of chiral rigid bidentate bridging ligands based on the N,N'-1R,2R-bicyclohexyl unit will induce the formation of helical structures when linked by a linear metal-connecting point. In this work we report the metal-organic nanotubular structure of {[CdL2 (NO3)(3H2O)]⋅NO3⋅2H2O} n  (2). Compound 2 crystallizes in the chiral space group P61, with one cadmium atom, one L2  ligand, one coordinated nitrate anion, three coordinated water molecules, one uncoordinated nitrate anion and two guest water molecules in the asymmetric unit. In the asymmetric unit of 2 (a), each Cd(II) atom is seven-coordinated to two nitrogen atoms that come from two different L2  ligands, one bidentate nitrate anion occupying two coordination sites, and three oxygen atoms from three different water molecules. The coordination environment around the cadmium centre can be described as a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal, with a Cd-N bond distance of 2.298(4)Å and Cd-O bond distances ranging from 2.296(6) to 2.534(6)Å. The N-Cd-N bond angle is 174.51(2)°, and the O-Cd-O bond angles range from 46.96(2)° to 83.39(9)°. Due to the reciprocal arrangement of the two C-Nimine bonds in the rigid R,R-1,2-bicyclohexyl moiety, the adjacent cadmium centers are connected to each other by the nitrogen donors (pyridyl) of the bridging bidentate L2  ligands to form an infinite right-handed helical chain with a pitch of 47.25Å, with each period corresponding to six L2  ligands (b). When viewed along the crystallographic c axis, the six successive Cd(NO3)(H2O)3 units are bridged by the bidentate backbones of L2  to form a hexagonal structure (c). Of particular interest is the observation that with the infinite helical chain running along the crystallographic c axis (d), the hexagonal structures are packed in an overlapping fashion around the crystallographic 61 axis to generate a huge one-dimensional hexagonal nanotube with an opening of ~1.2×1.2nm (e).
